context_meta.title: Sano won't be suspended by MLB after assault accusation
context_meta.summary: NEW YORK (AP) — Minnesota Twins third baseman Miguel Sano will not be suspended by Major League Baseball after being accused of assault. The commissioner's office said in a statement on Friday "there was insufficient evidence to support a disciplinary determination against Sano, due to conflicting and inconsistent witness accounts and the absence of contemporaneous substantiation." Sano was accused of assault in December by a photographer who has covered the Twins. She posted on Twitter that the All-Star third baseman forcibly attempted to kiss her following an autograph session at a mall in 2015. context_meta.title: Red Sox Release Statement On Steven Wright's 15-Game Suspension
context_meta.summary: Major League Baseball has made its decision regarding Steven Wright's arrest in December, suspending the Boston Red Sox knuckleballer 15 games for violating the league's Domestic Violence Policy. Wright was arrested at his home in Tennessee after he and his wife got into what the pitcher's lawyer described as a “verbal argument.” While acknowledging that an argument took place, both Wright and his lawyer were adamant the incident did not get physical. “We fully support MLB's Domestic Violence Policy, the discipline set forth by the Commissioner's Office, and Steven's acceptance of the ruling. Should Wright's suspension begin the first game of the season, he will be eligible to return Apr. 16 against the Baltimore Orioles.

context_meta.summary: Slugger J.D. Martinez moves to Boston, which hit the fewest homers in the American League. Also, six new managers: Alex Cora (Red Sox), Aaron Boone (Yankees), Dave Martinez (Nationals), Mickey Callaway (Mets) and Gabe Kapler (Phillies) try for the first time, and Ron Gardenhire (Tigers) returns after a four-year absence. context_meta.author: third_watch
context_meta.title: The fairly straightforward reason minor league baseball players deserve more money
context_meta.summary: In December of 1999, one of the few protections in place for minor-league baseball players put left-hander Johan Santana on the Twins. Santana, at that point, had never pitched above Class A ball, but had been in the Astros' system long enough to be subject to the Rule 5 Draft, which exists to prevent clubs from stashing Major League-ready players in their farm systems for too long. The rebuilding Minnesota Twins saw something they liked in Santana — in retrospect, it's not hard to figure out what — and scooped up Santana (with an assist from the Marlins) on the day of that draft. Players selected in the Rule 5 Draft must remain on the 25-man roster of their new teams for an entire season or be returned to their original organizations, so the Twins held on to Santana even though he was outright terrible in 2000.

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: MLB tried to debunk 'juiced balls' theory amid historic home run spike. Pitchers remain skeptical.
context_meta.summary: Last July, Major League Baseball issued a memo to every player on all 30 clubs as a direct response to the conspiracy theories circulating about the most crucial component of its product: the baseball itself. Countering rumblings that the league's baseballs were “juiced” to generate more scoring, MLB insisted its meticulous examination of game balls remained unchanged and the results categorically demonstrated the balls weren't any different. While position players shrugged their shoulders, pitchers weren't buying it. They wanted more proof nothing had changed. And nearly nine months later, as the 2018 season is set to open Thursday, skepticism remains. “I have questions. I have questions,” Washington

context_meta.title: Baseball players in minors to lose minimum wage protection
context_meta.summary: Minor league baseball players who make as little as $5,500 a season would be stripped of the protection of federal minimum wage laws under a provision in government spending legislation expected to be approved by Congress this week. The "Save America's Pastime Act" is included on page 1,967 of the $1.3 trillion spending bill and appears to pre-empt a lawsuit filed four years ago in U.S. District Court in San Francisco by three players alleging Major League Baseball and its teams violate the Fair Labor Standards Act and state minimum wage and overtime requirements for a work week they estimated at 50-to-60 hours. context_meta.title: Braves, A's, M's add express entrances for fans
context_meta.summary: Associated Press NEW YORK -- Three more major league teams are emphasizing life in the fast line -- for fans. Atlanta, Oakland and Seattle will open express entrances to members of CLEAR, expanding the fast-entry lanes to eight of the 30 big league ballparks. CLEAR is used at 24 U.S. airports to speed passage through security and opened at Yankee Stadium and Coors Field in 2015. It expanded to Marlins Park and Citi Field the following season and added Detroit's Comerica Park in 2017. "Sports venues are starting to look more and more like airports from a security and experience perspective," Lauren Stangel, CLEAR's head of sports and events, said Thursday. Is this the year it happens? For the last two seasons, the Red Sox finished with identical 93-69 records, winning the American League East both years. context_meta.title: Best bets for 2018 MLB over/unders
context_meta.summary: Derek Carty Daily Fantasy Close Follow on Twitter Over the past couple of years, Major League Baseball teams have gotten smarter about how they rebuild, tearing things down entirely without any regard for staying "competitive." The sport has been moving toward a stratification in team quality, whereupon there are several truly amazing teams and several truly awful teams. Those truly amazing teams are, of course, well-known, and so little edge exists in the betting market for them. When you look a step lower, though, there are a couple of teams pushing up much closer to this top tier than Vegas expects and offering plenty of edge as a result of this stratification. context_meta.title: Media Views: Some Cards games won't be on TV this year as embattled Facebok takes them
context_meta.summary: Facebook finds its business being scorched in a firestorm of controversy amid recent revelations about the social media giant's network being compromised by entities that have tried to influence voters in the United States. Personal information about Facebook users reportedly was compromised, and that has led to a social media campaign urging people to drop the service, under the #DeleteFacebook hashtag. All this had prompted Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg this week to acknowledging that “it was also a breach of trust between Facebook and the people who share their data with us and expect us to protect it. Major League Baseball has struck a deal in which 25 regular-season games will be streamed exclusively on Facebook this season and at least one will involved the Cardinals.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Modern major league manager salesman as much as strategist
context_meta.summary: TAMPA, Fla. Running a major league team for the first time in four seasons, 60-year-old Ron Gardenhire thought about all the data and video rammed into the microchip of his iPad, a slew of statistics his bosses hope transform defeats into triumphs. Baseball wasn't like this four decades ago, when Gardy left college to begin his career as an infield prospect in the low Carolina League, down in Lynchburg, Virginia. "If you're not changing, you're probably not going to last," the new Detroit Tigers manager said. "There's so much information out there. You have to use it." "I'm always going to be an old-school guy. I believe in prep and workouts and all that stuff and taking groundballs," he added.

context_meta.title: Minor League Ballplayers Will Lose Minimum Wage Rights As Part Of $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill
context_meta.summary: As part of a provision within the 2,232 page $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill that President Trump needs to sign before Friday to keep the government open, the Boys of Summer in the Minor Leagues would be exempted from a class of workers under federal labor law for minimum and overtime pay, which would quash several lawsuits by players seeking to earn a living wage. In doing so, a large portion of the players that dream of making it to the big leagues, yet never make it, will make salaries that can be as little as $1,100 a month. context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: MLB quoted the wrong document for July 4 hats
context_meta.summary: MLB has been known to break out holiday-themed hats over the course of the season. This week, we got a look at those caps for the 2018 season, the usual Father's Day, Mother's Day, Memorial Day and Fourth of July holidays were all included. The Independence Day caps have one major issue, though. The history is flawed. Inside the bill of each cap reads, "We The People," which is an objectively significant phrase in American history. It just doesn't have much to do with Independence Day. UniWatch's Paul Lukas was among the fans who pointed out the historical error. Fourth of July, of course, celebrates the Declaration of Independence, which was adopted on July 4, 1776. "We the People" is the opening

context_meta.title: MLB Power Rankings 2018: Where Each Team Stands Ahead of Opening Day
context_meta.summary: As Major League Baseball's 2018 season rapidly approaches, it's time to examine where all 30 teams are at as they begin their quest to win a World Series.  MLB is kicking things off earlier than normal this season, with all 30 teams in action on March 29. This marks the first time in 50 years that every club will play on the season's first day, per MLB.com's Mark Newman. On the heels of a strange offseason, in which most of the top free agents waited until at least February to sign deals, it's hard to know what will happen when games begin.  For now, though, there appears to be a clear dividing line between the true playoff contenders in both leagues and everyone else.  2018 MLB Power Rankings

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Professional Sports Leagues Go Head-To-Head With New Tax Code
context_meta.summary: A single four-letter word – added to a provision of the tax code – has professional sports leagues scrambling, as teams face what could be millions of dollars in new taxes. "Real." The revision changed a section of the tax code that applies to "like-kind exchanges." Under the old law, farmers, manufacturers and other businesses could swap certain "property" assets – such as trucks and machinery – without immediately paying taxes on the difference in value. The 2017 tax overhaul inserted the word "real" before "property." With that, the provision now applies only to real estate swaps. That means teams could be looking at tax bills in the millions for trading player contracts. Major League Baseball
